questions.text: What is the most common reason for an elevated reticulocyte count among the conditions?
questions.explanation:
Reticulocytosis

Reticulocytopenia

  • Hemolytic anemia
  • Acute blood loss
  • Therapeutic response to nutritional anaemia
  • Aplastic anemia
  • Nutritional anaemia
  • Iron deficiency
  • Vitamin B12 / B6 deficiency
  • Myelophthisic anemia
  • Myelodysplastic syndromes
  • Anaemia of chronic disease

questions.text: What is the most likely interpretation if Hemoglobin is 9 g/dL, MCV is 104 fL, MCH is 22 pg, and MCHC is 31 g/dL?

  • Iron deficiency anaemia
  • Thalassemia
  • Sideroblastic anaemia
  • Anaemia of chronic disease
  • Hemolytic anaemia

  • Cytotoxic drugs

questions.text: What is the Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) using Hemoglobin (Hb) level is 15 g/dL and Hematocrit (Hct) is 45%?
questions.explanation: MCHC (g/dl) = Hb x 100/ PCV or Hematocrit

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents for a routine check-up. His laboratory results show that his Hemoglobin (Hb) level is 14 g/dL, and his RBC count is 4.7 million cells/μL. Using these values, calculate the Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH).
questions.explanation: MCH (pg) = Hb x 10/ RBC count

questions.text: Calculate MCV in a patient where RBC count is 4.5 million cells per microliter (cells/μL), Hb 9gm/dl and Hematocrit is 30%
questions.explanation: MCV (fL) = PCV x 10/ RBC count

questions.text: RBC indices Definitions 1. MCV a) Indicates the variation in the size of red blood cells. 2. MCH b) Reflects the average volume of a red blood cell. 3. MCHC c) Measures the average amount of haemoglobin in a single red blood cell. 4. RDW d) Represents the amount of haemoglobin per unit volume of red blood cells.
questions.explanation:
RBC INDICES

DEFINITION

INTERPRETATION

MCV (Mean Corpuscular Volume)

Reflects the average volume of a red blood cell and is expressed as femtoliters (fl) or cubic microns (μm³).

MCV= PCV/RBC
  • <80fl= Microcytic
  • 80-100 fl= Normocytic
  • >80= Macrocytic

MCH (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin)

Measures the average amount of haemoglobin in a single red blood cell, expressed in picograms (pg).

MCH= Hb/ RBC
  • <27 pg = Hypochromic
  • 27-32 pg = Normochromic
  • >32 pg = Hyperchromic

MCHC (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration)

Represents the average concentration of haemoglobin in a given volume of red blood cells, expressed as grams per deciliter (g/dl).

MCHC= MCH/MCV

Normal value: 33-37g/dl

RDW (Red Cell Distribution Width)

Indicates the variation in the size of red blood cells (Anisocytosis), expressed as a percentage.

Normal Value: 11.5-14.5%

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with a fever and his blood sample was taken to measure ESR using the Wintrobe tube. What are the advantages of the instrument (A) over instrument (B)?

options.label: C
options.text: Useful for estimation of both PCV and ESR

questions.correct_answer: C. Useful for estimation of both PCV and ESR

2.5mm

ESR estimation

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate)?

options.label: B
options.text: Proportion of red blood cells in the total blood volume

options.label: C
options.text: Reflects the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood

ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate)

PCV (Packed Cell Volume)

Definition

It measures the rate at which red blood cells (erythrocytes) settle at the bottom of a test tube over a specified period, usually one hour.

PCV, also known as hematocrit, measures the proportion of blood volume occupied by red blood cells. (Option B)

Significance

Non-specific marker of inflammation 

No specific role in inflammation.

Increases in

Inflammation, fever, pregnancy, cancer

Polycythemia

Decreases in

Sickle cell disease, polycythemia, hypoproteinemia

Anemia

Reported in

Millimeter

percentage % (Option D)

Reference range

Male ≤15 mm/hr

Female ≤ 20 mm/hr

Child ≤10 mm/h

Male = 40% to 54%

Female = 36% to 48%.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with fatigue, palpitations, and shortness of breath. Examination reveals pallor. Using the following values, calculate the reticulocyte production index: Reticulocyte count: 5% Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL Hematocrit: 28%
questions.explanation:
RPI = CRC / maturation time in peripheral blood in days

Hematocrit

Maturation time

≥ 40%

1 Day

30-40%

1.5 Days

20-30%

2 Days

< 20%

2.5 Days

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the OPD with fatigue, weakness, and breathlessness. He shows pallor and icterus on examination. Given his hemogram results, reticulocyte count of 5%, haemoglobin of 9 g/dL, and hematocrit of 28%, calculate his corrected reticulocyte count.
questions.explanation: CRC= Observed reticulocyte count x Patient’s haemoglobin / Standard haemoglobin

questions.text: At which site does erythropoiesis primarily occur in an adult human?
questions.correct_answer: A. Bone marrow of long bones

questions.text: What is the approximate maturation time for reticulocytes in the bone marrow before they are released into the bloodstream as mature red blood cells?
What is the normal range for reticulocyte count in adults?

A 25-year-old woman experiences ongoing fatigue and weakness, appearing pale upon examination. Laboratory investigations reveal low haemoglobin levels, and a peripheral blood smear is ordered. Which stain is most effective for visualising reticulocytes in peripheral blood smears?
Which stage of erythropoiesis is characterised by the expulsion of the nucleus, resulting in a smaller, pyknotic cell with increased haemoglobin content?
Which condition is NOT typically associated with a dry tap during bone marrow aspiration?
If a person is 45 years old, what would be the expected percentage of cellularity in their bone marrow biopsy?
questions.explanation: % Cellularity =100 − age of the patient
